pullRequest.body:
We define (normalized) discrete valuations.

Co-authored-by: Filippo A. E. Nuccio <filippo.nuccio@univ-st-etienne.fr>

---

### PR summary [18a7469019](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21371/commits/18a7469019f61c84fc91aa97dd0af0f9b42c9afb)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.Valuation.Discrete.Basic` (new file)|999|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IsDiscrete`
`+ IsDiscrete.surj`
`+ isDiscrete_iff_surjective`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#21370~~

:v: mariainesdff can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
Before merging, I'd like to resolve the discussion about the naming.

> Before merging, I'd like to resolve the discussion about the naming.

Oh sorry, you're right.

Thanks!

bors d+

Thanks!

bors d+

```suggestion
import Mathlib.RingTheory.Valuation.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.GroupWithZero.Int
```

```suggestion
`Multiplicative.ofAdd (-1 : ℤ)` belongs to the image of `v`.
```
I think it would also be good to say what `A` is here (and why this corresponds to the usual definition in the literature).

```suggestion
  `Multiplicative.ofAdd (-1 : ℤ)` belongs to the image.
```

```suggestion
  `Multiplicative.ofAdd (-1 : ℤ)` belongs to the image. -/
```

I'm not sure that `IsDiscrete` is a good name; the point is (as far as I can see) that the discrete valuation is *normalized*. The discreteness is captured by the target group already.

Also, `one_mem_range` looks a bit strange as a name of a property that talks about `Multiplicative.ofAdd (-1)`. (I know that it does correspond to `1` being in the image in the usual setting. Perhaps add a comment?)

> I'm not sure that `IsDiscrete` is a good name; the point is (as far as I can see) that the discrete valuation is _normalized_. The discreteness is captured by the target group already.

We considered this point when naming this definition. We chose the name `IsDiscrete` partly for shortness (we did not want to use `IsNormalizedDiscrete` everywhere), but also because to declare a non-normalized discrete valuation in Lean, one just need to assume `(v : Valuation A ℤₘ₀)` with a nontriviality hypothesis, which for fields we defined as
```lean
/-- A valuation on a field is nontrivial if there exists a unit with valuation not equal to `1`. -/
class Nontrivial (w : Valuation K Γ₀) : Prop where
  exists_val_ne_one : ∃ x : Kˣ, w x ≠ 1
```
Hence, we do not think it is necessary to introduce a class for non-normalized discrete valuations (but we do prove many results without assuming the valuation to be normalized).

> Also, `one_mem_range` looks a bit strange as a name of a property that talks about `Multiplicative.ofAdd (-1)`. (I know that it does correspond to `1` being in the image in the usual setting. Perhaps add a comment?)

I will add a comment.
What is the argument against `IsNormalized` (which is not much longer than `IsDiscrete` and in my opinion better captures the relevant property more precisely)?

I want to have `Discrete` in the name of this definition because I think that will make it easier for people to find it and the related lemmas (I think people are more likely to search for `discrete` than for `normalized`). I discussed this with @faenuccio and he agrees.

```suggestion
  obtain ⟨π, hπ⟩ := hv
  refine WithZero.cases_on c ⟨0, map_zero _⟩ fun a ↦ ⟨π ^ (-a.toAdd), ?_⟩
  simp [hπ, ← WithZero.ofAdd_zpow]
```
Using `WithOne.cases_on` here is defeq abuse (as `ℤₘ₀` is defined as `WithZero ...` and not `WithOne ...`)
Changing to `WithZero.cases_on` also gets rid of the ugly `rfl` at the end (which says that `WithZero.coe a = WithOne.coe a`).

```suggestion
  ⟨fun _ ↦ IsDiscrete.surj v, fun hv ↦ ⟨hv _⟩⟩
```
This is actually slightly faster.
Can you use a `variable {K : Type*} [Field K]` line?

pullRequest.title: feat(RingTheory/Valuation/Discrete/Basic): define discrete valuations
